keyATM Covariate with PÃ³lya-Gamma Augmentation

Source: vignettes/pkgdown_files/keyATMPG.Rmd
keyATMPG.Rmd

Model

An alternative approach to model covariates is to use PÃ³lya-Gamma augmentation. Polson et al.Â (2013) propose a strategy to use PÃ³lya-Gamma latent variables for fully Bayesian inference in binomial likelihoods. Linderman et al.Â (2015) use it to develop models for categorical and multinomial data with dependencies among the multinomial parameters. We extend their method to incorporate covariates.

We use the same notations as in the main text. Our corpus contains DD documents. We observe a matrix ğ—\mathbf{X} of MM covariates whose dimension is DÃ—MD \times M. Topic model assigns one of KK topics to each observed word. ğ³d\mathbf{z}_d is a vector of assigned topics for a document dd. We introduce the stick-breaking representation of the multinomial distribution () described in Linderman et al.Â (2015), ğ³dâˆ¼ğ–²ğ–¡-ğ–¬ğ—ğ—…ğ—ğ—‚(nd,ğ›™d).\begin{align} \mathbf{z}_{d} &\sim \textsf{SB-Multi}(n_d, \boldsymbol{\psi}_d). \end{align} rewrites the KK-dimensional multinomial distribution with Kâˆ’1K-1 binomial distributions.

ğ–²ğ–¡-ğ–¬ğ—ğ—…ğ—ğ—‚(ğ³dâˆ£nd,ğ›™d)=âˆk=1Kâˆ’1ğ–¡ğ—‚ğ—‡(ndkâˆ£ndâˆ’âˆ‘kâ€²<kndkâ€²,Ïˆdk)=âˆk=1Kâˆ’1(Ndkndk)(exp(Ïˆdk)1+exp(Ïˆdk))ndk(11+exp(Ïˆdk))Ndkâˆ’ndk=âˆk=1Kâˆ’1(Ndkndk)exp(Ïˆdk)ndk(1+exp(Ïˆdk))NdkNdk=ndâˆ’âˆ‘kâ€²<kndkâ€²\begin{align} \textsf{SB-Multi}(\mathbf{z}_d \mid n_d, \boldsymbol{\psi}_d) &= \prod_{k=1}^{K-1} \textsf{Bin}(n_{dk} \mid n_d - \textstyle\sum_{k' < k} n_{dk'}, \psi_{dk}) \\ &= \prod_{k=1}^{K-1} \binom{N_{dk}}{n_{dk}} \bigg( \frac{\exp(\psi_{dk})}{1 + \exp(\psi_{dk})} \bigg)^{n_{dk}} \bigg( \frac{1}{1 + \exp(\psi_{dk})} \bigg)^{N_{dk} - n_{dk}} \\ &= \prod_{k=1}^{K-1} \binom{N_{dk}}{n_{dk}} \frac{\exp(\psi_{dk})^{n_{dk}}}{(1 + \exp(\psi_{dk}))^{N_{dk}}} \tag{1} \\ \label{eq:sb-multi} N_{dk} &= n_d - \sum_{k' < k} n_{dk'} \end{align}

We model the parameters in with the covariates. First, we assume that coefficients follow the multivariate normal distribution. ğ›Œ\boldsymbol{\lambda} is a MÃ—(Kâˆ’1)M \times (K-1) matrix, so we introduce the vectorization transformation to draw all elements from a single draw of the multivariate normal distribution.

vec(ğ›Œ)âˆ¼ğ’©(vec(ğ›0),ğšº0âŠ—ğš²0âˆ’1)ğšº0âˆ¼ğ’²âˆ’1(ğ•0,ğ›0)\begin{align} \text{vec}({\boldsymbol{\lambda}}) &\sim \mathcal{N}(\text{vec}(\boldsymbol{\mu}_0), \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0 \otimes \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_0^{-1}) \tag{2} \\ \label{eq:prior_lambda} \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0 &\sim \mathcal{W}^{-1}(\mathbf{V}_0, \boldsymbol{\nu}_0) \end{align} where we have the priors ğ›0=0\boldsymbol{\mu}_0 = \mathbf{0}, and ğšº0\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0 is a (Kâˆ’1)Ã—(Kâˆ’1)(K-1) \times (K-1) identity matrix (for topics). ğš²0\boldsymbol{\Lambda}_0 is a MÃ—MM \times M identity matrix (for covariates). ğšº0âŠ—ğš²0âˆ’1\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0 \otimes \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_0^{-1} becomes a diagonal matrix and equation (2) is the same as ğ›Œkâˆ¼ğ’©((ğ›0)k,(ğšº0)kkğš²0âˆ’1), for k=1,â€¦,Kâˆ’1\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{k} \sim \mathcal{N}((\boldsymbol{\mu}_{0})_{k}, (\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0)_{kk} \boldsymbol{\Lambda}_0^{-1}), \text{ for } k = 1, \ldots, K-1.

Next, we use covariates to model the parameters in . ğ›™dâˆ¼ğ’©(ğ›ŒâŠ¤ğ±d,ğšº0)\begin{align} \boldsymbol{\psi}_d &\sim \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\lambda}^\top \mathbf{x}_d, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0) \end{align} Social scientists often use categorical variables (e.g., authorship of the document) as covariates. Modeling the mean of the multivariate normal distribution with covariates allows us to create variation in the document-topic distribution when two or more documents have the same set of covariates. The multivariate normal distribution can be generalized to the matrix normal distribution. ğš¿âˆ¼â„³ğ’©(ğŒ,ğ”,ğšº0),\begin{align} \boldsymbol{\Psi}\sim \mathcal{MN}(\mathbf{M}, \mathbf{U}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0), \end{align} where ğš¿\boldsymbol{\Psi} is a DÃ—(Kâˆ’1)D \times (K-1) matrix, each row of ğŒ\mathbf{M} is equal to ğ›ŒâŠ¤ğ±d\boldsymbol{\lambda}^\top \mathbf{x}_d, and ğ”\mathbf{U} is the DÃ—DD\times D identity matrix (documents are independent). This generalization will allow us to have a vectorized implementation.

Estimation

We sample ğ›Œ\boldsymbol{\lambda}, ğš¿\boldsymbol{\Psi}, and PÃ³lya-gamma auxiliary variables ğ›š\boldsymbol{\omega}.

Sampling ğš¿\boldsymbol{\Psi}

Equation (1) has the same form as Theorem 1 of Polson et al.Â (2013) and we can introduce P{'{o}}lya-gamma auxiliary variables.

p(ğ³d,ğ›šdâˆ£nd,ğ›™d)âˆâˆk=1Kâˆ’1exp((ndkâˆ’Ndk/2)Ïˆdkâˆ’Ï‰dkÏˆdk2/2)=âˆk=1Kâˆ’1exp(âˆ’Ï‰dk2(Ïˆdk2âˆ’2Ï‰dk(ndkâˆ’Ndk/2)Ïˆdk))âˆâˆk=1Kâˆ’1exp(âˆ’Ï‰dk2(Ïˆdkâˆ’1Ï‰dk(ndkâˆ’Ndk/2))2)=ğ’©(ğ›™dâˆ£ğ›€dâˆ’1ğ›‹d,ğ›€dâˆ’1)Ï‰dkâˆ¼PG(Ndk,Ïˆdk) for 1,â€¦,Kâˆ’1Îºdk=ndkâˆ’Ndk2 for 1,â€¦,Kâˆ’1ğ›€d=diag(Ï‰d1,â€¦,Ï‰d,Kâˆ’1)\begin{align} p(\mathbf{z}_d, \boldsymbol{\omega}_d \mid n_d, \boldsymbol{\psi}_d) &\propto \prod_{k = 1}^{K - 1} \exp \big( (n_{dk} - {N_{dk}}/{2}) \psi_{dk} - \omega_{dk} \psi_{dk}^2 /2 \big) \\ &= \prod_{k = 1}^{K - 1} \exp \bigg( -\frac{\omega_{dk}}{2} \bigg( \psi_{dk}^2 - \textstyle \frac{2}{\omega_{dk}} (n_{dk} - N_{dk}/2) \psi_{dk} \bigg) \bigg) \\ &\propto \prod_{k = 1}^{K - 1} \exp \bigg( -\frac{\omega_{dk}}{2} \bigg( \psi_{dk} - \textstyle \frac{1}{\omega_{dk}}(n_{dk} - N_{dk}/2) \bigg)^2 \ \bigg) \\ &= \mathcal{N}\big( \boldsymbol{\psi}_d \mid \boldsymbol{\Omega}_d^{-1} \boldsymbol{\kappa}_d, \boldsymbol{\Omega}_{d}^{-1} \big) \\ \omega_{dk} &\sim \text{PG}(N_{dk}, \psi_{dk}) \text{ for } 1, \ldots, K-1 \\ \kappa_{dk} &= n_{dk} - \frac{N_{dk}}{2} \text{ for } 1, \ldots, K-1 \\ \boldsymbol{\Omega}_{d} &= \text{diag}(\omega_{d1}, \ldots, \omega_{d, K-1}) \end{align} We can use the multivariate normal distribution to sample ğ›™d\boldsymbol{\psi}_d. p(ğ›™dâˆ£ğ³d,ğ›šd)âˆp(ğ³dâˆ£ğ›™d,ğ›‹d,ğ›€d)p(ğ›™dâˆ£ğšº0,ğ—,ğ›Œ)âˆğ’©(ğ›™dâˆ£ğ›Ìƒ,ğšºÌƒ)ğ›Ìƒ=ğšºÌƒ[ğ›‹d+ğšº0âˆ’1ğ›ŒâŠ¤ğ±d]ğšºÌƒ=[ğ›€d+ğšº0âˆ’1]âˆ’1,\begin{align} p(\boldsymbol{\psi}_d \mid \mathbf{z}_d, \boldsymbol{\omega}_d) &\propto p(\mathbf{z}_d \mid \boldsymbol{\psi}_d, \boldsymbol{\kappa}_d, \boldsymbol{\Omega}_d) p(\boldsymbol{\psi}_d \mid \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0, \mathbf{X}, \boldsymbol{\lambda})\\ &\propto \mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\psi}_d \mid \tilde{\boldsymbol{\mu}}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}) \\ \tilde{\boldsymbol{\mu}} &= \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}}[\boldsymbol{\kappa}_d + \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_0^{-1} \boldsymbol{\lambda}^\top \mathbf{x}_d] \\ \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Sigma}} &= [\boldsymbol{\Omega}_d + \boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{0}^{-1}]^{-1}, \end{align} where the second proportion comes from Matrix Cook Book 8.1.8 (product of Gaussians).

Sampling ğ›Œ\boldsymbol{\lambda}

Sampling ğ›Œ\boldsymbol{\lambda} and ğ—\mathbf{X} is the same as Bayesian multivariate linear regression in Rossi et al.Â (2012, pp.31-34).

Ordering effect

Stick-Breaking representation of the multinomial distribution has a potential ordering issue (Zhang and Zhou, 2017). We can regard as a distribution that orders categories according to their proportions. This can be an issue in because topics are pre-labeled, and the order does not necessarily match with the proportion of the topics.

Reference

  • Linderman, S. W., Johnson, M. J., & Adams, R. P. (2015). Dependent multinomial models made easy: Stick breaking with the PÃ³lya-gamma augmentation. Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems, 2015, 3456-3464.
  • Polson, N. G., Scott, J. G., & Windle, J. (2013). Bayesian inference for logistic models using PÃ³lya-Gamma latent variables. Journal of the American statistical Association, 108(504), 1339-1349.
  • Rossi, P. E., Allenby, G. M., & McCulloch, R. (2012). Bayesian statistics and marketing. John Wiley & Sons.
  • Zhang, Q., & Zhou, M. (2017). Permuted and augmented stick-breaking bayesian multinomial regression. The Journal of Machine Learning Research, 18(1), 7479-7511.
